SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Recurrence is a major cause of treatment failure after allogeneic transplantation for acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) and myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), and treatment options are very limited
Azacitidine is a DNA methyltransferase inhibitor with activity in myeloid disease
The authors hypothesized that low-dose azacitidine administered after transplant would reduce recurrence rates, and conducted a study to determine a safe dose/schedule combination
METHODS: Forty-five high-risk patients were treated
Median age was 60 years; median number of comorbidities was 3; 67% were not in remission

By using a Bayesian adaptive method to determine the best dose/schedule combination based on time to toxicity, the authors investigated combinations of 5 daily azacitidine doses, 8, 16, 24, 32, and 40 mg/m2, and 4 schedules: 1, 2, 3, or 4 cycles, each with 5 days of drug and 25 days of rest
RESULTS: Reversible thrombocytopenia was the dose-limiting toxicity
The optimal combination was 32 mg/m2 given for 4 cycles
One-year event-free and overall survival were 58% and 77%, justifying further studies to estimate long-term clinical benefit
No dose significantly affected DNA global methylation
CONCLUSIONS: Azacitidine at 32 mg/m2 given for 5 days is safe and can be administered after allogeneic transplant for at least 4 cycles to heavily pretreated AML/MDS patients
The trial also suggested that this treatment may prolong event-free and overall survival, and that more cycles may be associated with greater benefit
